Award.AwardTitle: Semidefinite Programming Methods for Moment and Optimization Problems
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project targets at solving moment and optimization problems. A moment is the integral of a polynomial over a set with densities. Optimization is about making a decision so that an objective is optimized. An exemplary question is how to find the lowest valley of an area full of uneven mountains. Semidefinite programming is an efficient tool for solving moment and optimization problems, because it provides mathematically easy descriptions for complicated sets. The research results made in the project will produce plenty of mathematical methods for solving various computational problems.

This project works on moment and optimization problems. A moment is the integral of a monomial with respect to a measure. Moment problems are about existences and constructions of measures satisfying some given properties. Optimization problems are about minimizing functions, typically nonlinear and nonconvex, globally over given sets. We propose semidefinite programming methods for solving these two kinds of problems. For moment problems, semidefinite programming can be applied to describe the set of moments of desired measures. For optimization problems, global optimum can be computed by minimizing linear functions in moment variables, subject to semidefinite programming constraints. These two kinds of problems are closely connected to each other by semidefinite programming. The main task of moment problems is to determine whether a given sequence can be represented as moments of a measure supported in a prescribed set. In optimization, we are mostly interested in computing global minimizers of nonlinear nonconvex functions. An efficient tool for unifying moment and optimization problems is semidefinite programming. The underlying mathematics includes convex geometry, duality theory, complex and real algebraic geometry, matrix theory, optimization theory, and scientific computing. The PI has expertise on the proposed subjects. Novel methods and tools for overcoming research challenges are proposed with supporting evidences. The research results produced by the project could not only make significant advances in the PI's field, but also generate novel methods for many other areas in computational mathematics. Moment and optimization problems have broad applications in science and engineering. Typical applications include: matrix theory, computational algebra, convex algebraic geometry, tensor computations. The moment and optimization problems in such applications have their own special features and properties. Education is an important part of the project. The students will get trained by taking advanced courses as well as conducting research activities. Achievements produced by the project will be disseminated to the scientific community timely in various outlets.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project is about moment and optimization problems. A moment is the integral of a monomial with respect to a measure. Moment problems are about existences and constructions of measures satisfying some given properties. Optimization problems are about minimizing functions, typically nonlinear and nonconvex, globally over given sets. Semidefinite programming is an efficient tool for solving moment and optimization problems.

The PI worked on optimality conditions in polynomial optimization. The local optimality conditions are constraint qualification conditions, Karush-Kuhn-Tucker conditions, complementarity conditions, and second order sufficient/necessary conditions. The global optimality condition is the weighted sum-of-squares representations, which corresponds to Putinar's positivsetllensaz in real algebraic geometry. These two types of optimality conditions appear differently, but they are closely connected by beautiful mathematics. The PI proved that Lasserre's hierarchy of semidefinite relaxations has finite convergence, when the usual standard constraint qualification, strict complementarity, and second order sufficiency conditions of nonlinear programming hold at all global minimizers. Moreover, he aloso showed that these sufficient conditions hold generically at every minimizer, whenever a fixed degree bound on the defining polynomials exist. Because of his contributions, the PI was awarded the Prize for Young Researchers of the INFORMS Optimization Society.

The PI worked on symmetric tensor decompositions.  There is a one-to-one correspondence between symmetric tensor decompositions and consistent generating matrices. For general tensors, the decomposition uniquely determines  the consistent generating matrix, and vice versa.  The PI invented a novel method for computing symmetric tensor decompositions. Because of the importance of this result, the PI was awarded the SIAG/LA Best Paper Prize, in the SIAM Conference on Applied Linear Algebra, May 4-8,  2018.

The PI worked on the hierarchy of local minimums in polynomial optimization. For this purpose, he first computes H-minimums, for which the first and second order optimality conditions are satisfied. To compute each H-minimum,  the PI constructed a sequence of semidefinite programming relaxations, based on optimality conditions. After H-minimums were found,  a method for obtaining all local minimums is given. 

The PI worked on real eigenvalues of symmetric tensors. The largest or smallest eigenvalue can be found by solving a polynomial optimization problem, while the other middle eigenvalues can not. The PI proposed a new method for computing all eigenvalues sequentially, from the largest to the smallest. He showed that each eigenvalue can be computed by solving a finite number of semidefinite programming relaxations.

The PI worked on tensor eigenvalue complementarity problems.  He proved that for each eigenvalue, there is a unique eigenvector, up to scaling, for general tensors. This result implies that the number of normalized eigenvectors is also generally finite.  For the hard case of non copositive tensors, they proposed a method that can compute all complemetarity eigenvalues, by using semidefinite programming relaxations and randomization techniques. They showed that each eigenvalue can also be computed by solving a hierarchy of semidefinite relaxations.

The PI worked on bilevel polynomial optimization problems. He transformed them into equivalent semi-infinite polynomial programs and proposed efficient computational methods for solving them.  The usage of Jacobian representations greatly improved the computational efficiency. For a classical family of bilevel polynomial programs, they proved the convergence of the proposed method.

The PI worked on postive maps and separable matrices.  The PI studied how to check if a linear map is positive or not and how to check if a matrix is separable or not. He proposed semidefinite programming relaxation methods for the related optimization problems. To check the positivity of a linear map,  he constructed a hierarchy of semidefinite relaxations for minimizing the associated bi-quadratic forms over the unit spheres. He proved that the positivity can be detected by solving a finite number of semidefinite programming relaxations. To check the separability of a matrix, he constructed a hierarchy of semidefinite programming relaxations. If it is not separable, a mathematical certificate for that can be obtained; if it is,  a separable decomposition can be obtained.
